questions.correct_answer: A. Hypertrophy and drooping of eyelid
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hypertrophy and drooping of eyelid

Highyeild:

Chronic irritation worse in the morning. Hyperaemia and telangiectasia of anterior lid margin Scales around base of lashes ( collarettes ) Scarring and hypertrophy scarring and notching ( tylosis ) of the lid margin, trichiasis (misdirected eyelashes), madarosis (loss of lashes) or poliosis (loss of pigmentation of lashes)

Extraedge:

PATHOPHYSIOLOGY Several mechanisms by which staphylococci may alter meibomian gland secretion and cause blepharitis are:- Direct infection of the lids Evoke reaction to staphylococcal exotoxin Provoke allergic response to staphylococcal antigens.

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient presented with glaucoma with bulging cornea. What is the most probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratoconus Keratoconus is a condition where the cornea , typically a dome like round structure that helps focus light as it enters the eye, becomes bulged and deformed into a more conical shape.

Highyeild:

Classical signs of keratoconus:- Fleischer's ring :- an iron colored ring surrounding the cone Vogt's striae:- stress lines caused by corneal thinning Apical scarring:- scarring at the apex of the cone Corneal thinning:- In advanced cases, the thinning of the central cornea can be seen on examination. Visual Acuity:- Reduced visual acuity due to oblique astigmatism Retinoscopy :- scissor reflex Ophthalmoscopy :- Oil droplet

Extraedge:

Risk Factors Cause Unknown Family History Down Syndrome. Marfan Syndrome. & Ehlers Danlos History Of Other Eye Conditions (Ex. Aniridia) Chronic Eye Rubbing Signs & Symptoms Visual Impairment Refractive Errors Irregular Astigmatism Abnormal Cornea Curvature Cornea May Bulge In Cone Shape During Exam Acute Hydrops Reduced Vision

Table:

#MANTRA Treatment:- Glasses Or Contact Lenses To Correct Refractive Errors Rigid Contact Lenses L Correct Astigmatism Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking Where Riboflavin Eye Drops Used Uv Treatment To Cornea To Become Stiffer Corneal Transplant

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the below histopathology picture of retinal pigment epithelium?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Drusen Above retinal histopathology image is of Drusen characteristic feature of ARMD , i.e., Age-related macular degeneration. Drusen are a hallmark of ARMD. On histopathology, nodular drusen appear as eosinophilic dome-shaped structures situated between Bruch’s membrane and the displaced, attenuated RPE overlying the drusen. Drusen displays dense PAS-positivity.

Highyeild:

Age-Related Macular Degeneration: " Dry” ( non-neovascular or atrophic ) Early stage, less severe 85%-95% of cases Most common symptom is blurry vision 3 Stages : Early, Intermediate, & Advanced " Wet" (neovascular or exudative) More severe than "Dry" ARMD Early symptom: Straight lines appear wavy Central vision blind spots develop Two subtypes: Occult & Classic

Extraedge:

They may become more basophilic with accumulation of calcium . Von Kossa staining may reveal calcific granules or calcific stippling within such calcified drusen. The size and density of drusen are determinant factors in the progression of the disease.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Stenopaic slit is used for all except-
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Corneal tattooing The stenopaic slit found in all the trial sets is 1–2 mm by 15–35 mm in size . It splits an opaque disc into two halves. It has many uses in ophthalmology. Fincham’s test is used to differentiate that colored halos are due to early cataract or acute congestive glaucoma related corneal decompensation. A stenopaic slit is passed across the pupil and haloes are observed. If those are broken halos, cataract is the most common cause . If brightness is reduced but haloes are intact , cornea is the common cause. Stenopaic slit is useful in finding out the axis of the cylinder. Stenopaic slit is used in cases of corneal opacities to find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy. After dilating the pupil with a mydriatic, the slit is rotated in front of the eye and the axis which gives maximum clarity is chosen for optical iridectomy.

Highyeild:

Histopathology Corneal Tattooing Shows:- electron dense granules are found within keratocytes and between collagen fibrils. In histologic evaluation, keratocytes can retain tattoo particles of non-metallic dyes within their cell membrane .

Extraedge:

Complications of corneal tattooing include:- corneal infection, inflammation, pain, and Risk of inadvertent globe penetration via entry into the anterior chamber. Keratopigmentation with micronized mineral pigments was performed in light sensitivity, color fading and neovascularization

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following is used as an adjuvant therapy for fungal corneal ulcer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atropine eye drops Treatment usually includes antifungal medications depending on sensitivity. Atropine eye drops are given to release ciliary spasms and to give symptomatic relief. Dexamethasone is contraindicated as it will cause immunological suppression and hence flaring of infection. Pilocarpine is not given as it will cause constriction of pupil and hence will aggravate pain. Lidocaine has no role and also it will cause reduced sensation and hence can aggravate complications.

Highyeild:

Signs Opacity in the cornea which will take up fluorescein stain as the epithelium will be abraded. Pupils will be constricted and sluggishly reactive due to irritation to the iris. This toxic reaction can produce hypopyon which will be sterile in bacterial ulcers. In fungal ulcer fungal hyphae may be present.

Extraedge:

Stages Stage of progressive infiltration Stage of active ulceration Stage of regression Stage of cicatrization

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following is not an ocular manifestation of Dengue virus infection?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cataract Fundus changes reported in literature due to dengue fever include: Macular edema Retinal hemorrhages Peripapillary hemorrhages Roth spots Diffuse retinal edema Exudative retinal detachment Optic neuritis is reported in dengue fever and is very rare. Anterior segment complication which is described in dengue is uveitis . Cataract is never described in literature in dengue fever

Highyeild:

Warning Signs:- Abdominal pain Persistent vomiting Clinical fluid accumulation Mucosal Bleed Lethargy, restlessness Liver enlargement>2cm Laboratory : increase in HCT concurrent with rapid decrease in platelet count

Extraedge:

Causes Of Cataract:- CONGENITAL Familial Intrauterine infections Maternal drug ingestions AGE Elderly METABOLIC Diabetes Hypocalcaemia Wilson's Disease Galactosemia DRUG - INDUCED Corticosteroids Miotics Amiodarone Phenothiazines TRAUMATIC AND INFLAMMATORY Post intraocular surgery Uveitis DISEASE ASSOCIATED Down's Syndrome Dystrophia Myotonica Lowe's Syndrome Atopic dermatitis

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of lesion of internuclear ophthalmoplegia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Medial longitudinal fasciculus Internuclear ophthalmoplegia: It occurs in lesions of the MLF. When the person tries to look towards the right side , the impulses from the right Abducens nucleus does not reach the left oculomotor nucleus resulting in failure of adductio n of the left eye. It is also associated with nystagmus of the right eye.

Highyeild:

Anterior INO Eyes are divergent Paralysis of both medial recti Seen in midbrain infarcts, multiple sclerosis Posterior INO There is a painless onset of visual disturbance, No diplopia in primary gaze Medial longitudinal Fasciculus involved the affected eve shows impairment of adduction when both eyes are tested simultaneously The contralateral eye abducts, however, with nystagmus. This is reversed when patient looks to opposite side in bilateral involvement

Extraedge:

Other conditions that can cause INO include: Brainstem encephalitis Behcet's disease, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the blood vessels Cryptococcosis, a fungal infection associated with AIDS Guillain-Barre syndrome 000 Lyme disease and other tick-borne infections Lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus) Head trauma Brain tumors

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to OPD with the complaints of gIare during night drive. He had underwent cataract surgery 1 year back. The best corrected visual acuity is RE - 6/12 and LE - 6/9 No improvement with pinhole. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior capsular opacification Posterior Capsular Opacification/After Cataract/Secondary Cataract Causes :- Older patients and Hydrophobic acrylic lenses and square edged silicone lenses. Residual lens matter—when all the cortex is not removed completely during cataract extraction Proliferative type—the anterior epithelial cells proliferate → dysplasia → opaque cells (Waddl cells) Symptoms : Gradual painless loss of vision after 6 months of cataract surgery Glare

Highyeild:

Types : Membranous - thin/dense Soemmering’s ring → peripheral ring shaped opacity between anterior and posterior lens capsule. So visual axis clear → asymptomatic Elschnig’s pearls → soap bubble like appearance migrating towards the visual axis Treatment : When the visual axis is clear → no need of treatment ND YAG laser capsulotomy (1064 nm wavelength and photodisruption in action) Dissection with cystotome

Extraedge:

Other uses of Nd VAG laser: Peripheral iridotomy in angle closure glaucoma Anterior vitreolysis in vitreous wick syndrome Suture lysis

Table:

#MANTRA Cataract post-operative complications Ocular area Post-operative complication Incision Wound leak Wound dehiscence Cornea Astigmatism Oedema/bullous keratopathy Anterior segment Pressure rise Endophthalmitis Capsule block syndrome Capsule Late tear with IOL Posterior capsule opacification Zonules IOL/bag decentration Sunset syndrome Iris Pupil capture Epithelial ingrowth IOL Opacification Inflammation Retina/vitreous Cystoid macular oedema Retinal detachment Choroidal haemorrhage

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the complains of protrusion of the right eye– 10 days with no h/o fever. CT-scan showed well-defined mass in the orbit with irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which is positive for Desmin in immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rhabdomyosarcoma Rhabdomyosarcoma: The most common primary malignancy of the orbit in children Arises from the pluripotent mesenchymal cells which have the potential to differentiate into striated muscles. Histopathological types: Embryonal: Spindle shaped cells (most common, 80%) Alveolar: Round cells Pleomorphic sarcoma Botryoid: Grape-like cells Immunohistochemically , the tumor shows positive for skeletal proteins like myosin, desmin, alpha-actin and myoglobin. Management : Since orbit has less lymphatics, if the tumor is confined to the orbit, the prognosis is good Treatment : Radiotherapy, chemotherapy, orbital exenteration

Extraedge:

EMBRYONAL Favorable clinical outcome Affect younger male patients Most commonly arise in the head, neck, and genitourinary regions Loss of heterozygosity at the imprinted 11p15 locus Loss of the maternal allele and duplication of the paternal allele Encodes the IGF-2 growth factor

questions.text: In 3rd nerve palsy all of the following are seen except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Impaired pupillary reflex In 3rd nerve palsy, Pupil is fixed and dilated due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle. So option D is not seen.

Highyeild:

Paralysis of the third cranial nerve Clinical features of third nerve palsy include: Ptosis due to paralys is of the LPS muscle. Deviation- E ye ba ll is turned down, out and s li ghtly intorted due to actions of the lateral rectus and superior oblique muscles. Ocular movements are limited in a ll the directions except outward. Pupil is fixed and dilated due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle. Accommodation is completely lost due to paralysis of the ciliary muscle . Crossed diplopia is elicited on raising the eyelid. Head posture may be changed if pupi ll ary area remains uncovered.

Extraedge:

Causes of isolated 3rd nerve palsy Idiopathic - about 25% Vascular Hypertension & Diabetes - (commonly pupil sparing) Aneurysm - posterior communicating - artery at its junction with internal carotid artery Trauma - subdural hematoma with uncal herniation Miscellaneous SYMPTOMS Drooping of eyelid Binocular double vision Pain (may be present)

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A patient is taking drugs for rheumatoid arthritis and has a history of cataract surgery 1 year back, the patient presented with sudden painless loss of vision, probable diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CME In the given question there is a history of rheumatoid arthritis in patients. Rheumatoid arthritis is most commonly associated with uveitis . Along with this patient underwent cataract surgery 1 year back followed by sudden painless loss of vision. Postoperative complications:- Diagnosis PCO Elevated lOP CME AU HLA-B27-associated uveitis 4 2 0 JRA 0 0 0 FHIC 2 1 0 Rheumatoid arthritis 0 2 3 Idiopathic uveitis 6 2 4 PU VKH 2 2 2 Behcet’s disease 4 4 1 Total 18/74 13/74 10/74 AU = anterior uveitis, CME = cystoid macular edema, FHIC = Fuchs heterochromic cyclitis, rap = intraocular pressure, JRA = juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, PCO = posterior capsular opacification, PU = panuveitis, VKH = Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada disease. Hence, most probably leakage around macula shown in given image most likely due to CME. Macular hole is a different entity having no association with rheumatoid arthritis and has a different fundal picture. Choroiditis shows healed scars or patches in the retina which have more likely infectious causes. Quinine-induced toxicity particularly shows Bulls eye maculopathy which has a different image as shown below. Image shown in the question is most probably of cystoid macular edema. Hence, answer is A.

Highyeild:

SYMPTOMS : Decreased central visual acuity Metamorphopsia Micropsia Ocular irritation Photophobia Conjunctival Injection OCULAR MANIFESTATIONS 90D EXAMINATION: Blurring of normal RPE and choroidal background Pockets of fluid in the outer plexiform layer Largest pockets centrally , progressively smaller cysts peripherally Yellow spot (diffusion of luteal pigment) evident in the central macula Small intraretinal and intracystic hemorrhages , microaneurysms , telangiectasias may be seen

Extraedge:

Pathogenesis:- VITREOMACULAR TRACTION: INFLAMMATION:

Table:

#MANTRA Cystoid Macular Edema:-

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presented with headache and blurring of vision. On examination there was diplopia on looking towards left in the right eye. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Demyelination It is a Cause of horizontal diplopia. Typically, symptoms and examination findings , i.e., diplopia on looking towards the left in the right eye is characteristic of internuclear ophthalmoplegia. INO is the result of damage to the medial longitudinal fasciculus. This is a nerve fiber leading to the brain. The damage may be due to many causes. A stroke can be called ischemia or an ischemic attack. Strokes most commonly affect older people and affect only one eye. In MS, the INO usually affects both eyes.

Highyeild:

Anterior INO Eyes are divergent Paralysis of both medial recti Seen in midbrain infarcts, multiple sclerosis Posterior INO There is a painless onset of visual disturbance, No diplopia in primary gaze Medial longitudinal Fasciculus involved the affected eve shows impairment of adduction when both eyes are tested simultaneously The contralateral eye abducts , however, with nystagmus . This is reversed when patient looks to opposite side in bilateral involvement

Extraedge:

Other conditions that can cause INO include: Brainstem encephalitis Behcet’s disease, a rare condition that causes inflammation of the blood vessels Cryptococcosis, a fungal infection associated with AIDS Guillain–Barre syndrome Lyme disease and other tick-borne infections Lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus) Head trauma Brain tumors

Table:

#MANTRA
